div1.p: Dunshie lists the cases of yellow fever at Guanajay Barracks, Cuba. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Report from J. F. Dunshie to the Chief Surgeon, August 25, 1900
div1.opener:
Post Hospital, Guanajay Barracks, Cuba,
August 25, 1900
To the
Chief Surgeon, Dept Western Cuba,
Quemados, Cuba.
Duplicate
Sir,
div1.p:
In compliance with paragraph 119, Manual for the Medical
Department, I have the honor to report the following list of patients that
have had and are new suffering from Yellow Fever at this Post.

1- On Wednesday, July 4th. Pvt. Samuel Walker, Co. “I” 1st. U.S. Infty. was admit-
ted to receiving tent at Post Hospital, Guanajay Barracks with some tem-
perature; he complained of pains in head, back of neck, back and was vomit-
ing at time of admission. On July 6th albumen was found in
his urine in large quantities; that and other symptoms enabled the Surgeon
in charge to make a diagnosis of Yellow Fever; then upon the recommanda-
tion of the Post Commander he was moved to Civil Hospital in Guanajay / C
City , where there had been a case of Yellow Fever under treatment some
time previous. The patient was moved with the object of preven-
ting infection of Hospital and Post and the spread of the disease.
Doctor Louis Gallinania, a thouroughly competent Cuban Physician, who is in
charge of said Hospital,treated the above named soldier until the time of
his death which was July 9th at 3.30 P.M.

The company quarters in which his Company was stationed was cleared of
all bedding and company property, and the interior of building white wash-
ed. The bedding etc. was disinfected in a solution of Mercury
Bichloride.

All efforts on the part of the Surgeon and Post authorities to trace the
origin of the disease proved fruitless. Soldier was inclined to
intemperance and probably concealed some of his movements during the few
days prior to his being taken sick.

Although he denied emphattically that he had visited any of the houses
of prostitution where women from the infected district of Havana are at
times temporarily quartered, it was the opinion of the Surgeon and others
that he had done so and very probably contracted the disease during one
of his visits to some one of said houses.

2-On July 20th Sergt. George Smith, Co. “I” 1st. U.S. Infty. was admitted to
receiving tent at Post Hospital, Guanajay Barracks, with a temperature of I00
100f. He complained of severe head ache and pains in back, legs ect.

Albumen was found in urine July 20 in large quantity. When admitted
patient was suffering from a severe case of Generrhea. He had
visited the City of Havana, Cuba a few days before he was taken sick and
probably contracted the Yellow Fever at that place. Patient
remained in Hospital until July 29th, at which time he was returned to
quarters and returned to duty August 5th. 1900.

3-On July 20th, 1900, Pvt. William Davidson, Co. “I”? 1st. U.S. Infty. was admitt
ed to receiving tent at Post Hospital, Guanajay Barracks, with a tempera-
ture of 100f. He complained of severe pains back of head, eyes, back
and legs. No albumen was found in his urine. Patient had been in
the City of Havana, Cuba a few days before he was taken sick and probably
contracted the disease at that place. He remained in Hospital
until July 29 at which time he was returned to quarters and returned to
--2--
duty August 5, 1900.

4- On July 21st, 1900 Pvt. Arthur Fastheff, Co “M” 1st. U.S. Infty., a patient in
hospital had a temperature of 103f. at 4 o'clock P.M. he was first admitted
to Post Hospital July 9th / suffering from Generrhea and Chancreids. He
was circumcised July 16th and had been confined to his bed from this time
to date of first temperature. On July 21st Patient complained of
severe pains in head and general pains or soreness all over body.

He was removed from ward after examination of blood had been made for
Malarial Plasmodium, and placed in a receiving tent. Albumen appeared
in his urine in large quantity July 25th, urine was examined daily and urine
appeared in more and less quantities at each examination.

On July 30th. patient became delirious and remained in that condition unt
until 5 o'clock August 5th. 1900, at whitch time death occurred

5- On July 21st. Pvt Harry b Watson, Co. “M” 1st. U.S. Infty., a patient in
Hospital had a temperature of 102 f. at 4 o'clock P.M. He was taken from
the ward and placed in a receiving tent and urine examined.. No album
men was found but other symptoms warranted diagnosis of yellow fever
being made. Patient complained of severe pains in head and ANGs.
He was first admitted to Hospital July 16th. suffering from Diarrhoea and
probably contracted disease in the Hospital. He has now entire-
ly recovered and is waiting transportation to join his organization.

6- On July 21st. Pvt. John D. Schweiger, Hospital Corps was admitted to
receiving tent with a temperature of 102.6f. He complained of
pains in head and soreness of legs and was vomiting when admitted to
Hospital. Albumen was found in his urine on July 26th. and in-
creased in quantity for three or four days, then began to decrease.
Pvt. Schwieger had been on duty as nurse at the Post Hospital up to the
time of being taken sick and probably contracted the disease while on
duty. His temperature became normal July 31st. and he is now rapid-
ly recovering and will be able for duty in a few days.

7- On July 21st Pvt Nels Rasmussen, Hospital Corps was taken sick and place
in the receiving tent. His temperature on being admitted was 101f.
and he was vomiting, but had no pains except a severe head ache.

No albumen was found in his urine. His highest temperature
was 102.8f July 22, and decreased steadily until normal was reached July
27. Patient was returned to duty August 9th. 1900.

8- On July 28 Pvt Owen Mercer, Co. “I”, 1st U.S. Infty. was admitted to receiv-
ing tent at Post Hospital, Guanajay Barracks, with a temperature of 99.4f. He complained of severe head ache and Constipation. TTemperature in-
creased until August 8th. when 103.8f. was reached; after this temperature de
decreased. Albumen first appeared July 31st and increased for s
for several days. Patient is this date normal and recover-
ing rapidly.

9-- On July 28th Act. Hosp. Steward Claude M. Cook, Hosp Corps, was admitted
to receiving tent with a temperature of 103f. He complained of pains
in head, back of eyes and kidneys. Albumen first appeared in urine
July 31st and increased in quantity for three days then quantity began to
decrease. Steward Cook had been on duty at the Hospital contin-
uosly and had not been away from the Post and it is probable that he
contracted the disease while on duty connected with the Hospital.
He is now fully recovered and returned to duty this date.

10-- On August 7th Pvt John E Courtney, Hosp. Corps, was admitted to
receiving tent with a temperature of 101f. He was suffering pains
in head, back and lower portion of legs. Albumen found in urine Augus
8th. Patient is now rapidly recovering and will be able for duty in
a few days.

11-- On August 7th Sergt. Sylvester Haines, Co, “I” 1st. U.S. Infty. was admit-
ted to receiving tent at Hospital with a temperature of 102.8f. He was
suffering severe pains in head and back and was vomiting when admitted
No albumen was found in his urine. Patient is now doing well
and will be out of the Hospital in a few days.

12-- On July 16, 1900 Pvt. Harry Vance, Co? “M” 1st U.S. Infty. was admitted to
Post Hospital, Guanajay Barracks, Cuba with a duoble fracture of lower Jaw
He was kept in General Ward with other patients untill July 24th, when
all patients were taken from the wards and placed in tents.
On August 7 at 7 o'clock he complained of severe head ache,, temperature
was taken and found to be 101 f. He was put in a seperate tent and urine
examined and albumen found. Later in the day he complained of severe
pains in back and lower portions of legs. His highest tempera-
ture was
On August 14th patient had a severe attack of Uremic Coma, due to suppres-
sion of Urine. His temperature at this date is normal and he wi
will be ready for duty in a short time.
No new cases of yellow fever nor temperatures since August 7, 1900.
div1.closer:
Respectfully submitted, J.F. Dunshie Ac/Asst. Surgeon, U.S. Army,
Surgeon.
